task1_youtube_transcripts_drc.title: M23 Rebels Suspend Peace Talks with DR Congo Amid Mining Disputes

transcript_chunks.speaker: Reporter
transcript_chunks.text: The M23 rebels have suspended peace talks, citing lack of progress on mineral resource sharing in eastern DRC.

transcript_chunks.speaker: M23 Representative
transcript_chunks.text: Control over mining areas like Rubaya is essential; the government must consult local communities before concessions.

transcript_chunks.speaker: Analyst
transcript_chunks.text: This escalation ties directly to cobalt and coltan mines, where rebels accuse the army of favoring foreign investors.

task1_youtube_transcripts_drc.title: Congo Miners Struggle to Survive Under M23 Rebel Control

transcript_chunks.speaker: Miner Interviewee
transcript_chunks.text: Under M23, we pay taxes to rebels instead of the government; no consultation on how mining affects our villages.

transcript_chunks.speaker: Journalist
transcript_chunks.text: Artisanal miners in the east face forced labor and environmental damage from uncontrolled extraction.

transcript_chunks.speaker: Expert
transcript_chunks.text: The 2018 Mining Code requires community involvement, but ongoing war prevents proper consultations.

task1_youtube_transcripts_drc.title: Why is the U.S. Negotiating a Minerals Agreement with the DRC

transcript_chunks.speaker: Panelist
transcript_chunks.text: Trump's administration pushes for minerals access amid M23 conflicts, but locals demand rights consultations.

transcript_chunks.speaker: Diplomat
transcript_chunks.text: The deal includes security guarantees, but ignores community impacts on mining concessions.

transcript_chunks.speaker: Critic
transcript_chunks.text: Without ILO 169 ratification, indigenous and local groups in mining areas have no formal FPIC protections.
